externalDocs.description: find out more about facebook's web-apis

info.description: this zero-dependency package will provide a javascript-client for facebook's web-apis, with a working web-demo
info.title: swgg-facebook

facebook-graph.access_token.app.required.description:
App access tokens are used to make requests to Facebook APIs on behalf of an app rather than a user. This can be used to modify the parameters of your app, create and manage test users, or read your apps's insights.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/access-tokens/#apptokens

https://developers.facebook.com/tools/accesstoken/
facebook-graph.access_token.app.required.name: access_token

facebook-graph.access_token.page.require.description:
Page access tokens are used in Graph API calls to manage Facebook Pages. To generate a page access token, an admin of the page must grant an extended permission called manage_pages.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/access-tokens/#pagetokens

https://developers.facebook.com/tools/accesstoken/
facebook-graph.access_token.page.require.name: access_token

facebook-graph.access_token.user.require.description:
The user token is the most commonly used type of token. This kind of access token is needed any time the app calls an API to read, modify or write a specific person's Facebook data on their behalf. User access tokens are generally obtained via a login dialog and require a person to permit your app to obtain one.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/access-tokens/#usertokens

https://developers.facebook.com/tools/accesstoken/
facebook-graph.access_token.user.require.name: access_token

facebook-graph.test-user-id.required.description:
A test user associated with a Facebook app. Test users are created and associated using the /{app-id}/accounts/test-users edge or in the App Dashboard.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/apps/test-users#managetool

https://developers.facebook.com/apps/{app-id}/roles/test-users/
facebook-graph.test-user-id.required.name: test-user-id

facebook-graph.user-id.required.description:
A user represents a person on Facebook. The /{user-id} node returns a single user.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/user/
facebook-graph.user-id.required.name: user-id

facebook-graph.version.required.description:
The Graph API has multiple versions available to access at any one time. Each version contains a set of core fields and edge operations. We guarantee that those core APIs will be available and un-modified in that version for at least 2 years from release. The platform changelog can tell you which versions are currently available.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/overview/#versions
facebook-graph.version.required.name: version

get.description:
App access tokens are used to make requests to Facebook APIs on behalf of an app rather than a user. This can be used to modify the parameters of your app, create and manage test users, or read your apps's insights.

Limitations
Some user data that would normally be visible to an app that's making a request with an user access token isn't always visible with an app access token. If you're reading user data and using it in your app, you should use a user access token instead of an app access token.

App access tokens are considered insecure if your app is set to Native/Desktop in the Advanced settings of your App Dashboard and therefore will not work with API calls. This is because we assume that native or desktop apps will have the app secret embedded somewhere (and therefore the app access token generated using that secret is not secure).

Generating an App Access Token
To generate an app access token, you need to make a Graph API call:

GET /oauth/access_token
    ?client_id={app-id}
    &client_secret={app-secret}
    &grant_type=client_credentials
This call will return an app access token which can be used in place of a user access token to make API calls as noted above. Again, for security, app access token should never be hard-coded into client-side code, doing so would give everyone who loaded your webpage or decompiled your app full access to your app secret, and therefore the ability to modify your app. This implies that most of the time, you will be using app access tokens only in server to server calls.

Note that because this request uses your app secret, it must never be made in client-side code or in an app binary that could be decompiled. It is important that your app secret is never shared with anyone. Therefore, this API call should only be made using server-side code.

There is another method to make calls to the Graph API that doesn't require using a generated app access token. You can just pass your app id and app secret as the access_token parameter when you make a call:

https://graph.facebook.com/endpoint?key=value&access_token=app_id|app_secret
The choice to use a generated access token vs. this method depends on where you hide your app secret.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/access-tokens/#apptokens
https://developers.facebook.com/apps/

Represents a user gaining an achievement in a Facebook game. Not to be confused with an achievement type. 

Reading
GET /v2.11/{achievement-id} HTTP/1.1
Host: graph.facebook.com

Publishing
You can publish achievements by using the /{user-id}/achievements edge.

Deleting
You can delete achievements by using the /{user-id}/achievements edge.

Edges
/comments
Comments on the achievement story.
/likes
Likes on the achievement story.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/achievement/

delete.description:
A test user associated with a Facebook app. Test users are created and associated using the /{app-id}/accounts/test-users edge or in the App Dashboard.

Reading
Permissions and fields for read operations on this node are identical to those of the regular /{user-id} node.

Publishing and Updating
You can publish to this node to update the test user's password or name.
POST /v2.11/{test-user-id} HTTP/1.1
Host: graph.facebook.com
password=newpassword&name=Newname+Smith

Deleting
You can delete a test user by making a delete operation on this node.
DELETE /v2.11/{test-user-id} HTTP/1.1
Host: graph.facebook.com

Edges
/friends
The friends of the test user - this edge can be used to friend two test users.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/test-user/

post.description:
A test user associated with a Facebook app. Test users are created and associated using the /{app-id}/accounts/test-users edge or in the App Dashboard. You can publish to this node to update the test user's password or name.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/test-user/

parameters.description: New name for the test user.
parameters.name: name

parameters.description: A new password for the test user.
parameters.name: password

get.description:
A user represents a person on Facebook. The /{user-id} node returns a single user.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/user/

Facebook Pages this person administers/is an admin for. Permissions. manage_pages or pages_show_list is required to return Pages on which this person has a role. It will return empty data without proper permissions.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/user/accounts/

parameters.description: Filter pages by a specific business id.
parameters.name: business_id

parameters.description: If specified, filter pages based on whetherthey are associated with a Business manager or not.
parameters.name: is_business

parameters.description: If specified,filter pages based on whetherthey are places or not.
parameters.name: is_place

parameters.description: If specified, filter pages based on whether they can be promoted or not.
parameters.name: is_promotable

get.description:
The Graph API for achievements enables you to publish achievements in your game so players can tell more meaningful and relevant stories. Using the /{user-id}/achievements edge you can publish a new achievement for a user, read the achievements that a user has already collected, or delete an achievement collected.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/user/achievements/

parameters.description: If set, only actions produced by this app will be returned.
parameters.name: app_id_filter

parameters.description: If set, only action associated with this object will bereturned.
parameters.name: object

parameters.description: If set, only action associated with this object will bereturned.
parameters.name: type

tags.description:
The Graph API is the primary way to get data out of, and put data into, Facebook's platform. It's a low-level HTTP-based API that you can use to programmatically query data, post new stories, manage ads, upload photos, and perform a variety of other tasks that an app might implement.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/overview/
https://developers.facebook.com/docs/graph-api/reference/
https://developers.facebook.com/tools/explorer/
tags.name: facebook-graph

tags.description:
Facebook Login for Apps is a fast and convenient way for people to create accounts and log into your app across multiple platforms. It's available on iOS, Android, Web, Windows Phone, desktop apps and devices such as Smart TVs and Internet of Things objects.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/overview/
tags.name: facebook-login
